dt: {bc}a large strong rope usually of wire used to support a mast

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}stæg{/it}; akin to Old Norse {it}stag{/it} stay
shortdef: a large strong rope usually of wire used to support a mast

dt: {bc}to secure upright with or as if with {a_link|stays}
{bc}to incline (a mast) forward, aft, or to one side by the stays

shortdef: to secure upright with or as if with stays
to incline (a mast) forward, aft, or to one side by the stays

dt: {bc}to continue in a place or condition {bc}{sx|remain||}

dt.t: went for a short vacation but {wi}stayed{/wi} on for weeks

dt: {bc}to keep even in a contest or rivalry
{bc}to call a poker bet without raising
{bc}to stick or remain with (a race, a trial of endurance, etc.) to the end
usually used in the phrase {it}stay the course{/it}
{bc}to stop or delay the proceeding or advance of by or as if by interposing an obstacle {bc}{sx|halt||}
{bc}to check the course of (something, such as a disease)

pt: {sc}defer{/sc} {sc}postpone{/sc} {sc}suspend{/sc} {sc}stay{/sc} mean to delay an action or proceeding. {sc}defer{/sc} implies a deliberate putting off to a later time.
{sc}postpone{/sc} implies an intentional deferring usually to a definite time.
{sc}suspend{/sc} implies temporary stoppage with an added suggestion of waiting until some condition is satisfied.

pt.t: business will be {it}suspended{/it} while repairs are underway

pt: {sc}stay{/sc} often suggests the stopping or checking by an intervening agency or authority.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}estei{/it}-, {it}estai{/it}-, stem of {it}ester{/it} to stand, stay, from Latin {it}stare{/it} {ma}{mat|stand|}{/ma}
shortdef: to continue in a place or condition : remain

dt: {bc}the action of halting {bc}the state of being stopped
{bc}a stopping or suspension of procedure or execution by judicial or executive order
{bc}a residence or sojourn in a place

shortdef: the action of halting : the state of being stopped
a stopping or suspension of procedure or execution by judicial or executive order

dt: {bc}a thin firm strip (as of plastic) used for stiffening a garment or part (such as a shirt collar)

et: Middle English, from Middle French {it}estaie{/it}, of Germanic origin; akin to Middle Dutch {it}stake{/it} pole, Middle Low German {it}stak{/it} post, {it}stake{/it} pole {ma}{mat|stake|}{/ma}
shortdef: one that serves as a prop : support
a thin firm strip (as of plastic) used for stiffening a garment or part (such as a shirt collar)
a corset stiffened with bones —usually used in plural

dt: {bc}to provide physical or moral support for {bc}{sx|sustain||}
{bc}to fix on something as a foundation

shortdef: to provide physical or moral support for : sustain
to fix on something as a foundation

cxs.cxl: past tense and past participle of

dt: {bc}remaining in one's residence, locality, or country
{bc}remaining at home especially to tend to children and domestic duties while a spouse is at work

shortdef: remaining in one's residence, locality, or country; especially : remaining at home especially to tend to children and domestic duties while a spouse is at work

dt: {bc}to not go near someone or something {bc}avoid

dt.t: I know I shouldn't go there, but it's hard to {it}stay away{/it}.
He usually {it}stays away from{/it} large crowds.
I try to {it}stay away from{/it} caffeine.

shortdef: to not go near someone or something : avoid —usually + from

dt: {bc}to not leave at the present time

dt.t: You can go on ahead. I'll {it}stay behind{/it} to help clean up.

shortdef: to not leave at the present time
